Not so. I'm speaking as a person who has experienced EMDR. It helped me process traumas that were "stuck" in my psyche. fifteen years after EMDR I am still healthy and happy.

See first part of my response above.

I strongly recommend you find an EMDR clinician who is certified as an EMDRIA-Approved Consultant, or who is an EMDR Institute Facilitator (both constitute the highest levels of EMDR training). However, also "triangulate" the references with recommendations from similar therapists and don't be afraid to ask/tell the therapist(s) about your concerns. (see: http://drpattilevin.com/how-to-choose-a-therapist/)
As a parent, I completely understand your concerns. As a parent AND as an EMDR therapist, I encourage you to find the right EMDR clinician!

As Dr. Shapiro noted above, "E.M.D.R. therapy is an eight-phase approach. The first two of these phases- history-taking and preparation... [are essential]. Stabilization and the development of skills and self-capacities, like the ability to self-soothe and tolerate emotions, are the primary focus in the preparation phase of E.M.D.R. treatment." With a very experienced EMDR clinician, there should be no risk or danger to the client since the ability to handle strong emotion (should any arise) is "front-loaded" in the preparation phase. No EMDR therapist wants a client to feel flooded by emotion or to ever walk out of the office in less than a calm and comfortable state, but rather with built-in resources to cope with anything that might come up between sessions. In my 30 years of being a psychotherapist, the past 17 using EMDR as one of my most successful methods have delighted and impressed me with the gentleness of the approach. I have NEVER seen it make things worse. Thus a very experienced EMDR clinician will prepare your daughter exceedingly well and proceed carefully and judiciously to achieve a successful outcome. EMDR is a terrific and expeditious method for dealing with the aftermath of an attack, which often results in depression, or worsening a pre-existing depression.

I would appreciate more information, and more objective information, about the risks of this therapy, particulary as to whether there is a risk of triggering reactions that the patient cannot handle.  My daughter was physically attacked, and her therapist has recommended EMDR.  My daughter struggles with depression and I need to understand if there is a risk that this therapy could make things worse if it's not successful.  The story presented here does not seem complete, or at least not as complete and objective as I expect from the NYT.

Like Bx, I have had a lot of relief from being treated with EMDR.  I suspect it's not for everyone, and that patients should be chosen carefully.  It helped me put to rest some emotional aspects of childhood trauma, and allowed me to function within an enormously dysfunctional family in a way that was productive.  I have seen a huge change in my ability to deal with people I didn't want to cut off, but who were also not going to change.  It was an important tool in my therapy, and I will not hesitate to use it again if appropriate.

In a review of the literature by Mark B. Powers, Jacqueline M. Halpern, Michael P. Ferenschak, Seth J. Gillihan, and
Edna B. Foa, entitled "A meta-analytic review of prolonged exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder", the authors concluded that "there was no significant difference between PE and other active treatments (CPT, EMDR, CT, and SIT)." One of the authors of this study, Edna Foa, is the originator of the prolonged exposure (PE) method so this was clearly not done by EMDR proponents.
http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S027273581000070X

In a 2011 update to the original Scott Lilienfeld article, which can be found at the bottom of the page in the above link, the author states:

"Since my 1996 Skeptical Inquirer article on EMDR was published, an enormous volume of well-controlled research on this treatment has appeared in print...
...The most reasonabIe conclusion to be drawn from the extant literature is that EMDR is no more effective than standard treatments that rely on exposure to anxiety-provoking stimuli...
...the findings reviewed above seem to suggest that for individuals with PTSD—but not for those with other psychological disorders—EMDR may be a viable alternative to cognitive-behavioral or behavioral therapies that rely on exposure."

He goes on to state that one should be suspicious of people who say that EMDR is more effective and use it instead of rather than in addition to other methods. Even if its true that EMDR is only equally effective, then it should be equally legitimate to use EMDR to treat PTSD.

Mr. Ortiz
In 2004, the American Psychiatric Association published “Practice Guidelines for the treatment of Patients with Acute Stress Disorder and Psttraumatic Stress Disorder” in which EMDR was recommended as an effective treatment for trauma reactions. This followed the American Psychological Association’s Clinical Division finding (“Update of empirically validated therapies” in “The Clinical Psychologist”) that identified EMDR as an efficacious treatment for PTSD. That finding came out in 1998 and so hass not make use of the last decade and a half’s worth of research.
CBChill
The rumor was false. I and colleagues pioneered the use of EMDR in the VA, where I was the director of an inpatient PTSD Program for 26 years. In fact, the Joint Clinical Practice Guidelines for PTSD of the U.S. Dept. of Defense and Dept. of Veterans Affairs identified EMDR as a category “A” treatment for PTSD, repeating a similar finding from 2004. EMDR is part of the U.S. Army’s trauma treatment training program.

Anthony-
In comparative research, EMDR is as effective as CBT and the exposure family; where time is tracked, EMDR is faster getting to the same level of success (see Rothbaum, et al’s 2005 NIMH-funded study that found EMDR and prolonged exposure equally effective with EMDR requiring less exposure and no homework). Further, EMDR apparently is more easily tolerated by patients as measured by drop-out rates: Carlson, et al, in 1998 found 0% drop-outs for combat veterans treated with EMDR, with 78% of the vets no longer meeting diagnostic criteria for PTSD, and results maintained at 3- and 9- month follow-ups while the best exposure based research with combat veterans (Monson, et al, 2006 and Schnurr et al, 2007) had drop-out rates of 20 – 30%.

Marina-
Incorrect; EMDR is an evidence based treatment if the guidelines of the Dept. of Veterans Affairs, Dept. of Defense, American Psychological Assoc., American Psychiatric Assoc., TRICARE, NIMH’s Therapy Advisor, Boards of Mental Health of Israel, Holland, France, the United Kingdom, and the International Society for Traumatic Stress Studies, to name some national and international agencies that have evaluated the research on trauma treatment therapies. Further, at this time, EMDR is the only therapy for PTSD that has shown structural changes in the brain after successful treatment.
Jeneba-
Incorrect; EMDR and hypnosis differ in a large number of ways but most significantly in EMDR’s requirement that the client not be in a trance state.

It is interesting to note that while in Europe EMDR is considered a highly credible treatment there is still much debate about EMDR in the US. EMDR is a first-line treatment of psychological trauma and recognized as such by all major guideline committees over the world. Meta-analyses have shown it is an effective treatment for PTSD (e.g., Bisson et al., 2007; Rodenburg et al., 2009), and comparisons of EMDR and trauma-focused cognitive behavior therapy (CBT) have revealed that EMDR is at least as effective as exposure therapy (CBT) in terms of treatment outcome or the speed of therapeutic change (National Institute for Health & Clinical Excellence, 2005; Nijdam et al., 2012). Also, there is strong evidence that EMDR is no exposure and that eye movements add to the treatment’s effectiveness (Lee & Cuijpers, submitted for publication) which is substantiated by a wide array of experimental studies (e.g., Andrade, Kavanagh & Baddeley, 1997; Engelhard, van Uijen, & van den Hout, 2010; Gunter & Bodner, 2008). How come that there is so much research that supports the beneficial effects of EMDR and that there is still controversy in the US (alone) whereas the scientific literature is so convincing about this?

Many opinions have changed since those days. In fact, many Vietnam vets were told that PTSD is something they had to live with for the rest of their lives. Unfortunately, too many vets believed those opinions! Today, we know that many of those opinions of yesteryear were archaic. I too am a vet from the Vietnam era.

I am a veteran and a licensed clinician. Every week I hear from veterans and their family members from across the nation who are seeking effective treatment in a timely manner. I treat veterans everyday with EMDR with significant results as demonstrated by pre- and post-treatment results. Interestingly, many request EMDR because of they have heard of its efficacy from others. These veterans are not so interested in opinions and academic discussions; rather they want treatment that works in a timely manner - that is the true measure - efficacy of treatment and continuity of care. Your question regarding the handling of emotions may be more indicative of the time period than a particular psychotherapy. While emotions are a part of human experience, skilled therapists of all models of psychotherapy (including EMDR) assist clients in coping with them in a healthy manner.

At Soldier Center (Soldier-Center.com) we are committed to offering effective treatment to our veterans in a timely manner. EMDR is an effective treatment which continues to make a significant difference in the lives of our veterans every day.
It's not really useful to have a deterrent of a particular strategy (EMDR) either. Can't you find something else to read?

I was quite surprised to see the comment stating that
" EMDR is not considered an evidence-based treatment for any condition by the APA"....it is, in fact, named as an evidence-based treatment for PTSD by the APA, the VA/Dept. of Defense, the International Society for Traumatic Stress Studies (ISTSS), the UK Dept. of Health, the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (NICE) and other international organizations. It is considered by those organizations to be equivalent in treatment effects to Exposure Therapy and CBT (EMDR is not Exposure Therapy by another name), if not more efficient and better tolerated. Many citations have already been named accordingly.
In addition, it is of interest to note that EMDR was named in 2011 to the National Registry of Evidence-based Programs and Practices (NREPP) by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA). Since trauma (PTSD) and substance abuse are commonly co-occurring conditions, EMDR is now considered a treatment worth utilizing for an "integrated trauma treatment" approach with addictions.

I am fairly amazed at the overt hostility expressed here in regard to the oil companies. Do not, however, count me as their defender. When they do wrong, they need to be exposed and held accountable, something they try very hard to prevent. Taking criminal action, however, would be a drastic step. When people are engaged in ordinary business practices, criminal prosecution is the nuclear option. It makes future business arrangements and operations much more difficult and represents something close to lethality. A government has ways to demand the responsible individuals be returned. They could, for example, shut down the entire operations of the company.

This appears to be more related to conducting a thorough investigation than necessarily making preparations of prosecutions. As such, it is the government's way of saying "You will be held accountable", and making certain that all the facts are gathered. Jail is probably more of a threat than a reality.

American companies, and citizens representing them, do business just about everywhere in the world. Freedom to resolve problems without criminal sanctions is an important part of free trade and commerce. While I don't worry about the individuals involved in this matter (they've got a big company behind them), I do not send up cheers when American citizens are retained on foreign shores, at least not until all the facts are known.
